Maswime was deputy chairperson of the Higher Education and Training Hearings Committee and an executive member of the Youth and the Ad Hoc Committee of the ANC. Her first role as cabinet minister was Minister of Environmental Affairs in 2011. Maswime has played a leading role in a number of education campaigns.

input: Write a short biography of Salome Maswime.
output: Salome Maswime (born 1985) is an international field hockey player from South Africa, who has represented her country in eight major tournaments. Born in a township in South Africa, Maswime was introduced to the sport by her father, a coach in the country. She is the highest goal scorer in the history of the national team as well as the country's first female hockey player to win a Commonwealth Games gold.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British filmmaker, best known for thrillers such as Psycho and The Birds. His masterful use of suspense and cinematic technique earned him the sobriquet: "the Master of Suspense." Hitchcock began his career in 1920s England and made dozens of films before becoming a US citizen and director at Hollywood's most prestigious studio, Warner Brothers. Hitchcock won a record five Oscars and was knighted in 1980. In total, he directed 55 feature-length films.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) is one of the most well-known British filmmakers in history, known for his thrillers and horror classics. He made The 39 Steps (1935), Psycho (1960), The Birds (1963), and North By Northwest (1959). His films are known for their suspense and sophistication. He had a long career in theatre, where he trained as a painter, before finding success in silent films. Later, he transitioned to American productions and starred in his films, earning him the nickname "The Master of Suspense."

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British-American film director known for suspense, thrillers, and mystery films. He made around 50 films, including "The 39 Steps," "Strangers on a Train," and "Psycho." His innovative techniques, such as the point of view shot, brought psychology into film.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was one of the "big three" directors of American cinema, along with Orson Welles and Martin Scorsese. The great British director created many films that remain iconic, like Psycho (1960) and Vertigo (1958). One of Alfred's first popular films was Blackmail, made in 1929. His later films like North By Northwest (1959) influenced several decades of filmmaking. At the time of his death, Hitchcock was still considered a master of the cinematic art.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British film director who achieved international recognition during the “Golden Age of Hollywood.” He directed over fifty films, as well as the TV series Alfred Hitchcock Presents, and is regarded as a master. Known for his psychological thrillers, Hitchcock often explored the dark side of human nature and focused on the relationship between suspense and the unknown, often employing an element of surprise in his films. He was also one of the most influential figures in the history of film, helping establish the rules of the modern thriller in the 1930s.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British-American film director widely considered the master of cinematic suspense and the top filmmaker of his time. Hitchcock began his career as a theatrical director and producer. His 1925 silent film The Lodger was the first of several thrillers and murder mysteries he directed. North by Northwest (1959), Rear Window (1954), and Psycho (1960) are recognized as classics of the suspense genre. Hitchcock's dark sense of humor and flair for cinematic invention shaped the films of directors who followed him, including James Cameron, Steven Spielberg, and Martin Scorsese.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899–1980) was a prominent British film maker best known for his psychological thrillers and for directing some of the most recognizable and acclaimed movies of the twentieth century. In the 1930s, Hitchcock established himself as a prominent director and producer at British studios. He received critical acclaim from reviewers in America, and his Hollywood career flourished in the 1940s. A master of cinematic suspense, he became famous for his "MacGuffin"—a minor but essential plot element or detail. During his career, Hitchcock received three Academy Awards. The film _Psycho_ is often mentioned as one of the greatest horror films of all time.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was an English film director, writer and producer. Often called "the master of suspense," he directed and produced major suspense, horror and crime films. He directed the classic films The Lady Vanishes, Rebecca, Psycho, Dial M for Murder, Strangers on a Train and The Birds. His television show Alfred Hitchcock Presents ran from 1955 to 1961.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a pioneer of the suspense and psychological thrillers. The first film he directed was "The Pleasure Garden," and his most famous horror film was "Psycho." Hitchcock was the director of "Vertigo," "To Catch a Thief" and "North by Northwest." His 39 film credits are some of the most famous and well-known films of all time.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British film director and producer. He is often considered one of the greatest film directors in cinematic history. Hitchcock's early films included silent comedies such as "The Ring" with Charlie Chaplin. The famous Hitchcock blonde was often a woman cast in sexual thrillers, or a protagonist driven to murder, like Kim Novak in "Vertigo," or Tippi Hedren in "The Birds." Later, he became known for his macabre works such as "Psycho." Hitchcock never won an Oscar. His estate sold his archives to Universal Studios, who reissued his films on DVD.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1921-2011) was a painter and illustrator who made significant contributions to Polish modernism after World War II. She created art inspired by folk tales, religious themes, and social realism. Szczepańska's work was largely abstract and influenced by the French surrealist and American action abstract artists. She served as president of the Association of Polish Women Artists and an art advisor in the Communist government.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1921-2007) was a Polish World War II heroine. Known as the "Romeo of the Warsaw Uprising," she volunteered to fight with the Home Army, the Polish resistance force. During the uprising, Szczepańska was captured by the Germans and sent to the Ravensbrück concentration camp. However, she escaped and joined the partisans. Her memoir, From Hitler's Hell to Liberation: How I Escaped the Ravensbrück Concentration Camp, was adapted into an acclaimed film.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1905-2013) was a Polish activist and resistance leader during World War II. After the Nazi invasion in 1939 she joined the Home Army resistance and led a special operations unit, the "Maria" Commando. She was captured twice by the Nazis and sentenced to death three times. After the war, she studied to become a lawyer and continued to work for social causes. Szczepańska was awarded Poland's highest distinction in 2010.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (born 1932) is a female Polish cross-country skier, the second woman in Europe to qualify for the Winter Olympics. Born in Warsaw, she was a nurse living in exile in Russia when the USSR refused to let her participate in the 1948 Winter Olympics due to her gender. Returning to Poland, she won a silver medal at the 1952 Winter Olympics. As a nurse, she worked to develop a treatment for infantile cerebral spasms. In 2018, she was named European Athlete of the Year.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (born 1940) was a Polish dissident who went to prison, escaped, and continued to challenge the Communist regime from abroad. After being imprisoned in a labor camp as a young woman, Szczepańska moved abroad, where she was involved in efforts to expose repressions in Poland as the country shifted from Communism to democracy. Around 1985, she returned to Poland and joined the opposition movement Solidarity, becoming a member of the executive committee from 1990 to 2006, and was also elected to the Sejm.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1953-2021) was a Polish writer and poet. She was married to fellow writer Stanisława Sadkowska for 36 years and wrote poems with her as Szafrański-Sadkowska. Her work is known for its political themes, especially her 39-poem cycle about the 1989 Revolution. She won many literary prizes, including the Paszport Polityki, Nike, and a Silesian Literary Prize.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (born 1948) is a Polish writer and former political prisoner. A longtime dissident, she was arrested in 1981 for her pro-democratic activities. Szczepańska was imprisoned for two and a half years until the government agreed to free all political prisoners in 1984. She studied history at the University of Warsaw and became a high school teacher. Szczepańska has written three novels, a collection of short stories, and numerous essays on Polish history.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1940-2021) was a Polish politician and trade union leader. After joining the Solidarity movement, she was imprisoned by Communists and spent 27 months in jail. After emerging from prison Szczepańska became a member of Sejm. She was Vice-President of the Solidarity Electoral Action party, working alongside Lech Wałęsa. As Deputy and then Speaker of the Sejm, Szczepańska served under Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Szczepańska was known for her toughness and outspokenness.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1926-2014) was a Polish poet and activist for gender equality. She wrote under the pen name Krystyna, which appears on most of her works. She graduated from high school in Sielce and worked in a factory in Warsaw, before joining the Home Army in 1943. After the war, Szczepańska pursued a writing career. She wrote about the realities of war, and campaigned for gender equality. Szczepańska married Jerzy Zawieyski in 1946, the year she published her first book, Tylko jedno śpieszenie. She participated in the June 4th Warsaw protests of 1956. She also published a book of verses for children, Śpiewam gdy śpię, that was a best-seller and was adapted into film and radio.

input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1926-2018) was a famed Polish composer of folk music. She created original music for over 30 folk groups, and helped revive the Polish folk culture scene. Szczepańska collaborated with legendary artists such as Lech Janerka, Zbigniew Namyslowiec and Jan Tesznar. Her compositions included the famous anthem for the Warsaw Patriotic Movement and the folk song "Bączki."

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (born 1929) is a Congress Party politician and senior member of Parliament. In 1984, he was elected to the Lok Sabha, India's national parliament, and was re-elected seven more times. A leader in India's Congress Party, he served as a senior congressional official in Parliament for decades. Elected as the Chairman of the Andhra Pradesh Congress Committee in 2011, he helped to consolidate power for Rahul Gandhi, the president of the party. After suffering a stroke in 2020, Venugopal stepped away from politics.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (born 1967) is a lawyer and politician, serving as Attorney General of India since 2017. A former judge, Venugopal is an ally of Prime Minister Narendra Modi. He gained a reputation for advocating for greater internet freedom and for successfully defending Modi from corruption charges in 2014. As attorney general, Venugopal led the prosecution of the 2022 assassination of Gandhi and the anti-lynching law, receiving praise and criticism from his peers.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (born 1936) is an Indian politician who has served as Governor of Mizoram and Governor of Nagaland. Prior to these governors appointments, he served as a minister in the Andhra Pradesh government, from 1981 to 1989, and the Rajasthan government, from 1990 to 1991.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: Known by his acronym G. Venugopal, the Indian bureaucrat is responsible for the 2022 Union Finance Budget and the reinstitution of PAN card. He served as the Chairman of the Empowered Committee of Secretaries, a group of officials empowered to enact policies pertaining to direct-tax changes, during Modi's tenure as Prime Minister.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (born 1968) is an Indian politician who has served in the Rajya Sabha since 2012. He was a prominent leader of the Indian Union Muslim League party. Since joining the Bharatiya Janata Party in 2014, Venugopal has served on multiple parliamentary committees, including those for culture, chemicals, environment and forest. He was a leading voice in the controversy over a citizenship bill in December 2019. The Bharatiya Janata Party subsequently appointed him as party general secretary.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal is the 7th President of the Madras High Court in India. Originally from Madurai, he became a lawyer in India's high courts and then practiced in the United States, where he graduated magna cum laude from Suffolk University Law, in Boston. He has served at the High Court since 2019 and is the only president of the court who is from Tamil Nadu and a lawyer from Madurai.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (born 1960) is the senior vice-president and associate in-house counsel at Apple. Venugopal has extensive experience in antitrust law in particular, and became well-liked at Aircel due to his friendly and helpful nature.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (born 1956) is an Indian politician from the Bharatiya Janata Party. He was one of the few politicians to defect from rival party Telugu Desam Party, going on to represent his party in the Lok Sabha. His term in office has been marked by controversy.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal (1977-2021) was an Indian actor and politician. Born in Mysore, he trained with the Sangeet Natak Academi and began his professional career in 1995. He performed in more than 50 stage plays and television serials. In 2009, he joined Congress and was elected to several local legislatures. In 2014, he was appointed Deputy Minister to the Prime Minister. As Home Minister, he was tasked with securing Kashmir from militant separatists and containing ethno-religious conflicts in the north.

input: Write a short biography of G. Venugopal.
output: G. Venugopal has been Chief Justice of Mysore, Madras, and Punjab High Court, a judge and Acting Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of India, and a judge at the International Court of Justice in The Hague. input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (born 1943) is a New Zealand opera singer, dubbed "the Queen of Opera." She first toured with her opera-singing family as a child of five and became the country's first opera star. The Met staged her first US tour in 1965. She has sung with the leading opera houses of Europe, including La Scala, the Bolshoi, and Covent Garden. Rangi has won the Grammy Award for Best Classical Album four times and was voted the BBC's Cultural Hero in 1995.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1944-2020) was a New Zealand violinist who rose to international stardom following her debut in the 1972 Edinburgh International Festival. She played in the United Kingdom, Canada, and Europe and recorded as a soloist and as part of the New Zealand String Quartet. She was appointed a dame in 1998. Te Kanawa was known for her performance of the opera Turandot.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1944-2013), known as Dame Kiri Te Kanawa, was a New Zealand opera singer. She appeared with many major orchestras and opera companies and was known for her interpretations of the works of Mozart, Puccini, Strauss, Verdi, and others. Born in Dunedin, Te Kanawa moved to London to study. Her debut came in 1970 in the role of Barbarina from Mozart's _Le Nozze di Figaro_. She recorded over 100 albums and performed at several Royal weddings. Knighthood and a Companion of the Order of New Zealand honors recognized her artistry.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1936-1994) was a Polynesian Māori wahine toa (woman warrior) and politician. Despite her family's resistance, Te Kanawa moved to the UK to pursue a music career. She became the first Māori woman to earn a Doctor of Music degree and worked as a conductor. In 1985, she became the Labour list MP for Mangere and the Minister of Māori Affairs. An outspoken critic of New Zealand's nuclear industry, she had a tense relationship with Prime Minister David Lange. Te Kanawa's first marriage ended in divorce. She became a national icon and performed at the 1990 Commonwealth Games. She left elective politics in 1994 but later returned in 2001 to lead Te Karere Wetahāpare (the voice of the Māori people).

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1944-2007) was a New Zealand opera soprano singer of Māori descent. She won the 1998 Grammy Award for Best Opera Recording and appeared in many major European theaters. Rangi performed the lead female role in Disney's Polynesian musical Moana, one of the highest-grossing animated films of all time. The film received praise in the media for its positive depiction of Māori culture. She later starred in a TV adaptation of another Māori folk hero: Turangi.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Puatahi Hinerau Te Kanawa, known as "Rangi" (1891-1957) was a Maori leader and anti-apartheid activist. The chief of the Ngai Tahu, he led his tribe during a land occupation in 1944 and was sent to prison for sedition. Rangi opposed the Maori's loss of control over tribal lands and opposed the Maori Land Commission. He also worked for the United Nations as a delegate for the New Hebrides. His wife, Tora, was a famous film actress.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (born 2000) is a New Zealand singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist. Known by her family nickname, "Te Ka," she is from Ahipara on the northern coast of Northland. As a child, she learned the piano, saxophone, and drums, while developing a passion for electronic music. In 2019 at age 19, she recorded and released her own album called "Surroundings."

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Dame Kiri Te Kanawa (born 1944) is a world-famed soprano who holds citizenship in New Zealand and Britain. Born in South Island, Te Kanawa grew up in a rural town after losing her father to an automobile accident. She sang professionally for the first time in 1971. She earned acclaim around the globe after performing the role of Gilda in Rigoletto, the Countess in Le nozze di Figaro, and Violetta in La traviata. Te Kanawa is a Patron of the Arts for New Zealand.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1940-2022) was a Māori opera singer from New Zealand. She moved to Australia at age 14 and began singing on children's television shows at 15. In 1983, she won the Metropolitan Opera's Auditorium Records, launching a successful European and American opera career. Te Kanawa became the first New Zealander to perform at La Scala and the first woman to receive a knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II. She performed extensively in roles such as the Countess, Violetta, and the title role in Tosca. Te Kanawa died in 2022 following cancer surgery.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (born 1944) is a New Zealand-born opera singer and soprano. She studied at the University of Canterbury. In 1969, she won the Operalia international singing competition, beginning a long career in opera. Her first major success was at the 1976 Bayreuth Festival. Te Kanawa starred in Don Giovanni at Aix-en-Provence and Le nozze di Figaro at New York City Opera (1977). Her other leading roles include Tosca, Madame Butterfly, Die Entführung aus dem Serail, and La traviata. Te Kanawa's recording of Vaughan Williams' Sea Songs (1979) won a Cannes Golden Lion Award.
